ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Best Practice for URI construction?
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Benjamin, ... I agree that there isn t a rigorous standard.  However, from a ... as a multi-dimensional query.   I would argue that current best practice

Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Best Practice for URI construction?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=231097723; y=mnYd1IGM_ZGT4tFjpvwgiMVgQvU4SQ4qN4VM471ffrz8WIK6fJa4bfYD6cvdxs4

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=US-ASCII;
	delsp=yes;
	format=flowed

Hi Benjamin,

On Dec 10, 2005, at 5:15 AM, Benjamin Carlyle wrote:
> Clients can traverse a hyperlink to http://www.example.com/US/MA/ 
> Boston
> and http://www.example.com/?country=US&state=MA&city=Boston just as
> easily. There is no best practice. There should be no best  
> practice. The
> best practice is to allow that publisher's URI space to evolve
> independently of any software implementation by a subscriber.

I agree that there isn't a rigorous standard.  However, from a  
usability standpoint, I read:

> http://www.example.com/US/MA/Boston

as a unique resource, whereas:

> http://www.example.com/?country=US&state=MA&city=Boston

as a multi-dimensional query.   I would argue that "current best  
practice" -- as represented by actual URLs in the wild -- is for  
individual resources to named by hierarchical URLs, with queries used  
for potentially multi-valued search results.  This may not -always-  
be the case, but I think it represents the "common" case.  Would you  
disagree?

-- Ernie P.




--Apple-Mail-11--647534056

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=ISO-8859-1
